elements.content: A series of isostructural coordination networks of formula [M2 IIMIII­(μ-OH)­(NPy3)­(bpdc)3]·xsolvent (M = Co, Ni, Fe) that exhibit a noninterpenetrated binodal (3,9)-net, the first reported hua topology networks, have been constructed from a 3-c ligand, tris­(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3), and a previously known 9-c trinuclear metal carboxylate cluster. The (3,9)-nets exhibit high void space and large uptake capacity for the high pressure storage of CH4 and CO2.

The (3,9)-nets exhibit high void space and large uptake capacity for the high pressure storage of CH4 and CO2.

elements.content: A novel noninterpenetrated binodal (3,9)-c net, the first example of a hua topology net, is constructed from a 3-c tris­(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3) ligand and a previously known 9-c trinuclear metal carboxylate cluster. An isostructural series of hua networks with the formula, [M2 IIMIII­(μ-OH)­(NPy3)­(bpdc)3]·xsolvent (M = Co, Ni, Fe), exhibit extra-large surface areas and high uptake capacity for the high pressure storage of CH4 and CO2.

An isostructural series of hua networks with the formula, [M2 IIMIII(μ-OH)(NPy3)(bpdc)3]⋅xsolvent (M = Co, Ni, Fe), exhibit extra-large surface areas and high uptake capacity for the high pressure storage of CH4 and CO2.

elements.content: The classification of coordination networks into their network topologies is of fundamental importance since the understanding of network topologies facilitates the development of families or platforms of closely related reticular architectures. Systematic changes to a network topology or the decoration of a network can yield valuable information concerning structure–function relationships allowing materials to be tailored for specific applications. Of particular interest, the incorporation of molecular building blocks (MBBs) based upon metal-carboxylate clusters can yield comparatively rare high connectivity nodes (> 6-c) that afford unique and novel network topologies. There are fewer topological options available for higher connectivity nodes; in the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database, there are many examples of uninodal 4-c nets (667) and 6-c nets (295), but comparatively far fewer examples of 9-c (33), 10-c (20), 11-c (7), and 12-c (14) uninodal nets. The pursuit of networks with high connectivity nodes is also driven by the enhanced stability that can be exhibited by these high connectivity nodes which should yield robust and stable structures that enable reversible gas adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The classification of coordination networks into their network topologies is of fundamental importance since the understanding of network topologies facilitates the development of families or platforms of closely related reticular architectures. Systematic changes to a network topology or the decoration of a network can yield valuable information concerning structure-function relationships allowing materials to be tailored for specific applications. Of particular interest, the incorporation of molecular building blocks (MBBs) based upon metal-carboxylate clusters can yield comparatively rare high connectivity nodes (> 6-c) that afford unique and novel network topologies. There are fewer topological options available for higher connectivity nodes; in the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database, there are many examples of uninodal 4-c nets (667) and 6-c nets (295), but comparatively far fewer examples of 9-c (33), 10-c (20), 11-c (7), and 12-c (14) uninodal nets. The pursuit of networks with high connectivity nodes is also driven by the enhanced stability that can be exhibited by these high connectivity nodes which should yield robust and stable structures that enable reversible gas adsorption.

elements.content: Homo- and heterometallic trinuclear clusters of the type [M3­(μ3-O)­(O2CR)6­(X)3] n− (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cr, etc., and X = coligand or solvent) containing either an oxo or a hydroxo center are particularly versatile nodes for construction of coordination networks since they can serve as trigonal prismatic 6-c nodes containing capping solvent molecules, as observed in MIL-88, or as 9-c nodes if their open metal sites are coordinated by linker ligands. There exist only a limited number of frameworks with binodal (3,9)-c topology with only 7 types of (3,9)-c nets registered in the RCSR database. The majority of these nets are constructed using mixed ligands containing both pyridyl and carboxylate groups in either a 1:1 or a 1:2 ratio and often in combination with a dicarboxylate coligand. Only one example of a (3,9)-c net, CPM-33 (with partitioned acs or pacs topology), that uses tris-pyridyl ligands has been reported. CPM-33 was formed by insertion of a tris-pyridyl ligand of the correct length into a MIL-88 type framework to yield the 9-c node. This “pore space partition” strategy yielded rigid materials with high CO2 uptake capacity under ambient conditions. The (3,9)-c pacs and xmz, and 9-c ncb topologies have been the most extensively investigated for gas sorption, presumably due to their robust nature. The ncb networks are uninodal and utilize linear ligands in their construction, while the xmz topology is a binodal network due to the use of tripodal ligands; both networks yield frameworks with high BET surface areas of up to 3000 m2/g. Additionally, both ncb and xmz topologies are known to exhibit flexible breathing behavior upon incorporation of longer length ligands.

elements.content: Herein, we present isostructural frameworks with Co, Fe, and Ni that feature a new (3,9)-c net that is the first example of a coordination network with hua topology. These nets are composed of a tris-pyridyl ligand, tris­(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3), and a dicarboxylate ligand, 4,4′-biphenyl­dicarboxylic acid (bpdc), in a 1:3 ratio. The large pore space available has been utilized to demonstrate the potential that the synthesized frameworks have for CH4 and CO2 gas storage applications.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present isostructural frameworks with Co, Fe, and Ni that feature a new (3,9)-c net that is the first example of a coordination network with hua topology. These nets are composed of a tris-pyridyl ligand, tris(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine (NPy3), and a dicarboxylate ligand, 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (bpdc), in a 1:3 ratio. The large pore space available has been utilized to demonstrate the potential that the synthesized frameworks have for CH4 and CO2 gas storage applications.

elements.content: All solvents and reagents were used as obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and TCI fine chemicals. A slightly modified procedure was used for the synthesis of the NPy3 ligand (Supporting Information). 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Jeol EX270 spectrometer operating at 270 MHz for 1H. Proton NMR chemical shifts were referenced internally to residual solvent resonances. Spectra were recorded at 298 K, and chemical shifts (δ), with uncertainties of ±0.01 Hz, are quoted in ppm. Coupling constants (J) are quoted in Hz and have uncertainties of ±0.05 Hz for 1H–1H. Deuterated solvents were obtained from Cambridge Stable Isotopes and used as received.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All solvents and reagents were used as obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and TCI fine chemicals. A slightly modified procedure was used for the synthesis of the NPy3 ligand (Supporting Information). 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Jeol EX270 spectrometer operating at 270 MHz for 1H. Proton NMR chemical shifts were referenced internally to residual solvent resonances. Spectra were recorded at 298 K, and chemical shifts (δ), with uncertainties of ±0.01 Hz, are quoted in ppm. Coupling constants (J) are quoted in Hz and have uncertainties of ±0.05 Hz for 1H-1H. Deuterated solvents were obtained from Cambridge Stable Isotopes and used as received.

elements.content: Dimethylacetamide (8.0 mL) was added to a mixture of NPy3 (40.0 mg, 0.0839 mmol), bpdc (63.2 mg, 0.260 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (63.0 mg, 0.260 mmol) in a glass vial to yield a red solution. The reaction mixture was shaken well at room temperature before being placed in an oven at 120 °C for 4 days to yield very dark red crystallites (50.3 mg, 44%). The mother liquor was removed, and the sample was soaked in DMA for 2 days. The sample was activated for sorption experiments by solvent exchange with acetonitrile (3 × 12 mL) over the course of 2 days before being heated at 60 °C for 16 h under vacuum.

elements.content: A red block crystal was mounted on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer employing monochromated Cu Kα radiation generated from a fine-focus sealed tube. Cell constants were obtained from a least-squares refinement against 9954 reflections located between 16.95 and 273.70° 2θ. Data were collected at 297(2) K with φ and ω scans to 137.65° 2θ. The data integration and reduction were undertaken with SAINT and XPREP, and subsequent computations were carried out with the XP SHELXTL-Plus graphical user interface. An empirical absorption correction determined with SADABS was applied to the data. The structure was solved in the tetragonal space group I41/amd (#141) by direct methods with SHELXT, then extended and refined with SHELXL-2016/4. The non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters. A riding atom model with group displacement parameters was used for the hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterization and Instrumentation

Crystallography for 1(Co) 

A red block crystal was mounted on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer employing monochromated Cu Kα radiation generated from a fine-focus sealed tube. Cell constants were obtained from a least-squares refinement against 9954 reflections located between 16.95 and 273.70° 2θ. Data were collected at 297(2) K with φ and ω scans to 137.65° 2θ. The data integration and reduction were undertaken with SAINT and XPREP, and subsequent computations were carried out with the XP SHELXTL-Plus graphical user interface. An empirical absorption correction determined with SADABS was applied to the data. The structure was solved in the tetragonal space group I41/amd (#141) by direct methods with SHELXT, then extended and refined with SHELXL-2016/4. The non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters. A riding atom model with group displacement parameters was used for the hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: Experiments were performed under nitrogen using a flow rate of 60 mL/min on a TA Q50 Instrument. The data were collected in the High Resolution Dynamic mode with a sensitivity of 1.0, a resolution of 4.0, and a temperature ramp of 20 °C/min from 25 to 500 °C. The data were evaluated using the T.A. Universal Analysis suite for Windows XP/Vista Version 4.5A.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

Experiments were performed under nitrogen using a flow rate of 60 mL/min on a TA Q50 Instrument. The data were collected in the High Resolution Dynamic mode with a sensitivity of 1.0, a resolution of 4.0, and a temperature ramp of 20 °C/min from 25 to 500 °C. The data were evaluated using the T.A. Universal Analysis suite for Windows XP/Vista Version 4.5A.

elements.content: Ultra-high purity grade N2, CO2, and CH4 were used for all measurements. Samples were degassed on a Smart VacPrep instrument prior to the analysis. Low pressure CO2 measurements were performed on a Micromeritics 3 Flex surface area and pore size analyzer at 273, 283, 293, and 298 K. A Julabo temperature controller was used to maintain a constant temperature in the bath through the duration of the experiment. Measurements with N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K were conducted on a Micromeritics TriStar II PLUS instrument where liquid nitrogen and dry ice/acetone baths were used, respectively. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas were determined from the N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K using the Micromeritics Microactive software. High pressure CO2 and CH4 isotherms were collected on a Micromeritics HPVA II-100 instrument from 0 to 35 bar for CO2 and from 0 to 70 bar for CH4. A background correction was performed by subtracting the adsorption of the empty cell from the obtained isotherms. The total methane uptake was calculated using the equation: n tot = n ex + ρbulk(P,T) × V p, where the values for ρbulk(P,T) were obtained from the NIST Refprop database and V p was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption

Ultra-high purity grade N2, CO2, and CH4 were used for all measurements. Samples were degassed on a Smart VacPrep instrument prior to the analysis. Low pressure CO2 measurements were performed on a Micromeritics 3 Flex surface area and pore size analyzer at 273, 283, 293, and 298 K. A Julabo temperature controller was used to maintain a constant temperature in the bath through the duration of the experiment. Measurements with N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K were conducted on a Micromeritics TriStar II PLUS instrument where liquid nitrogen and dry ice/acetone baths were used, respectively. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas were determined from the N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K using the Micromeritics Microactive software. High pressure CO2 and CH4 isotherms were collected on a Micromeritics HPVA II-100 instrument from 0 to 35 bar for CO2 and from 0 to 70 bar for CH4. A background correction was performed by subtracting the adsorption of the empty cell from the obtained isotherms. The total methane uptake was calculated using the equation: n tot = n ex + ρbulk(P,T) × V p, where the values for ρbulk(P,T) were obtained from the NIST Refprop database and V p was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K.

elements.content: The frameworks [M2 IIMIII­(μ-OH)­(NPy3)­(bpdc)3]·xsolvent (1­(M), M = Co, Ni, Fe) were synthesized by the reaction of tris­(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­amine (NPy3) and 4,4′-biphenyl­dicarbox­ylic acid (bpdc) with M­(NO3)2 (M = Co, Ni, Fe) in either dimethyl­formamide (DMF) or dimethyl­acetamide (DMA). Frameworks with (3,9)-c nets are typically constructed using mixed carboxylate-pyridyl ligands or combinations of dicarboxylate and carboxylate-pyridyl ligands to achieve the 2:1 ratio of carboxylate to pyridyl groups needed to form 9-c nodes. In the study herein, the 2:1 ratio of carboxylate to pyridyl groups is achieved through the use of separate dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands in a 3:1 ratio. Red crystals appropriate for single crystal analysis were obtained for 1­(Co).
elements.clean_text:
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION

Synthesis and Structure

The frameworks [M2 IIMIII(μ-OH)(NPy3)(bpdc)3]⋅xsolvent (1(M), M = Co, Ni, Fe) were synthesized by the reaction of tris(4-(4-pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)amine (NPy3) and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (bpdc) with M(NO3)2 (M = Co, Ni, Fe) in either dimethylformamide (DMF) or dimethylacetamide (DMA). Frameworks with (3,9)-c nets are typically constructed using mixed carboxylate-pyridyl ligands or combinations of dicarboxylate and carboxylate-pyridyl ligands to achieve the 2:1 ratio of carboxylate to pyridyl groups needed to form 9-c nodes. In the study herein, the 2:1 ratio of carboxylate to pyridyl groups is achieved through the use of separate dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands in a 3:1 ratio. Red crystals appropriate for single crystal analysis were obtained for 1(Co).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1­(Co) was solved in the tetragonal space group I41/amd (#141) with unit cell parameters of a = 21.6873(5) Å, b = 21.6873(5) Å, c = 76.453(2) Å. The central nitrogen in NPy3 is planar and serves as a 3-c node, while rotational disorder is present for the phenyl rings of the NPy3 ligand, which exhibits a “propeller-like” conformation typically observed for triphenylamines. Each Co center exhibits an octahedral coordination sphere with four O-donors from distinct bpdc ligands in the equatorial plane, one N-donor from NPy3 and coordination to the central μ-OH on the axial positions. The Co trimer is formed by the coordination of the O-donors in 6 bpdc ligands in a monodentate fashion, where each of the O-donors in the carboxylate anions are coordinated to separate Co centers. In the center of the Co trimer is a bridging hydroxyl group, μ-OH, which is coplanar with the Co atoms and exhibits a Co–O–Co angle of 120°. The Co centers in the trimer have a mixed valence configuration wherein two of the Co ions are in a +2 oxidation state and one of the Co atoms is in a +3 oxidation state. Coordination of N-donors from the NPy3 ligand on the axial position of the Co yields the 9-c node. At present, there are only a limited number of examples with the 9-c Co trimer in framework systems. The combination of the 9-c node from the Co trimer and a 3-c from the nitrogen in the NPy3 ligand yields a single 3D noninterpenetrated binodal (3,9)-c network. This new topology has been registered with the RCSR and assigned the three letter code hua. The hua topology (3,9)-c net has a point symbol of {421.​615}­{43} and contains 8 nodes and 24 edges in the space group I41/amd, which matches its crystallographic point group.

elements.content: The trigonal prisms in the hua net representing the 9-c node exhibit two different orientations; one depicted from the top triangle face and the second from the square side face of the prism (c). The 90° rotation in the orientation of the 9-c node results in roughly a tripling of the c axis (76.453 Å) when compared to the a and b axes (21.6873 Å). This differs markedly from the closely related xmz net where the trigonal prisms of the 9-c node are orientated facing the same direction (d). When the xmz and hua 3,9-nets are compared to the 6-c acs net, which has solvent bound on the axial positions, the 3-c node appears to play a controlling role in the orientation of the trinuclear cluster, where a greater rotation of the trigonal prism is observed in the 6-c acs net (e).

elements.content: (a) Linkers used in the synthesis of 1­(Co) and (b) depictions of the 3-c and 9-c nodes. Comparison of the (c) 3,9-c hua net and (d) 3,9-c xmz net where the axial positions of the trinuclear clusters are coordinated to N-donors to yield the 9-c node and (e) 6-c acs net where solvent is coordinated to the axial positions of the trinuclear cluster.

Comparison of the (c) 3,9-c hua net and (d) 3,9-c xmz net where the axial positions of the trinuclear clusters are coordinated to N-donors to yield the 9-c node and (e) 6-c acs net where solvent is coordinated to the axial positions of the trinuclear cluster.

elements.content: Large voids in the shape of a distorted octahedron exist in the network structure with dimensions of 10.847 Å between two NPy3 ligands stacked on each other, 13.382 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the bpdc ligand and 15.569 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the NPy3 ligand (Supporting Information). A void space of 71.5% was calculated by PLATON within the framework, and is reflected by the low crystallographic framework density of 0.525 cm3/g. The distorted octahedron results in larger internal volumes when compared to either the tetrahedral or the trigonal-pyramidal voids seen in other (3,9)-c nets.

elements.content: The isostructural analogues with nickel, 1­(Ni), and iron, 1­(Fe), were also synthesized and verified by PXRD, but neither yielded crystals suitable for single crystal analysis. All frameworks were activated for gas sorption by solvent exchange with acetonitrile, followed by removal of the solvent under vacuum. Loss in crystallinity was observed when solvent exchange was attempted for the frameworks in either methanol or dichloromethane. The large void space of 71.5% present in the frameworks is reflected in the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) thermograms of the synthesized frameworks. Mass losses of 50.9, 60.1, and 62.1% were observed for 1­(Co), 1­(Fe), and 1­(Ni), respectively, between 25 and 200 °C, which we attribute to the loss of either DMF or DMA from the pores of the framework. The lower mass loss of 1­(Co) may be a result of the instability of this analogue in air, which is also reflected in the PXRD patterns.

The large void space of 71.5% present in the frameworks is reflected in the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) thermograms of the synthesized frameworks. Mass losses of 50.9, 60.1, and 62.1% were observed for 1(Co), 1(Fe), and 1(Ni), respectively, between 25 and 200 °C, which we attribute to the loss of either DMF or DMA from the pores of the framework. The lower mass loss of 1(Co) may be a result of the instability of this analogue in air, which is also reflected in the PXRD patterns.

elements.content: The N2 isotherms at 77 K of 1­(Co), 1­(Ni), and 1­(Fe) all display a type I isotherm (a). The BET surface areas of 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) were determined to be 2552 and 2775 m2/g, respectively, which is comparable to previous reports in the literature (2316–2738 m2/g) for 9-c nets with ncb topology that contain ligands with biphenyl groups (). The lower surface of 1475 m2/g for 1­(Co) may be due to partial decomposition of the framework when exposed to air as suggested by the lower accessible pore volume determined from TGA (Supporting Information).

elements.content: The CO2 isotherm at 195 K for all frameworks from 0 to 1 bar displayed two-step behavior with the step occurring at ∼200 mbar (b). This two-step behavior has previously been observed in ncb and xmz networks and attributed to flexibility in the framework whereby a gating mechanism occurs as increasing pressure drives an expansion of the network to accommodate extra gas molecules. The highest uptake of CO2 at 195 K was observed for 1­(Fe) (508 cm3/g), followed by 1­(Ni) (486 cm3/g) and 1­(Co) (362 cm3/g). These values correlate to the BET surface areas calculated from the isotherm data of N2 at 77 K. The large pores (>13 Å) present within the framework allow for the ready diffusion of guests into and out of the pores in the framework. The uptakes of CO2 at 195 K of 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) in this study compare favorably to networks with the ncb topology, which exhibit CO2 uptakes of 500–550 cm3/g at 1 bar (Supporting Information).

elements.content: In the low pressure CO2 isotherm of 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) at 298 K, a modest 30 cm3/g was adsorbed by the frameworks, while 1­(Co) exhibited an even lower CO2 uptake of 25 cm3/g (c). CO2 isotherms collected at 273, 283, and 298 K (Supporting Information) were used to calculate the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of each of the frameworks using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation (d). The frameworks in this study exhibited similar Q st values between 20.0 and 22.7 kJ/mol, indicating a relatively low affinity of the framework toward CO2. This is perhaps unsurprising given the pore sizes and a pore chemistry with no particular affinity for CO2. 1­(Ni) exhibited the highest Q st of 22.7 kJ/mol, followed by 1­(Co) and 1­(Fe) with Q st values of 20.0 and 20.4 kJ/mol, respectively. Upon increasing the CO2 loading (to 2.0 mmol/g), the Q st value starts to decrease (to 17.5–20 kJ/mol) toward the energy required for the enthalpy of liquefaction for CO2 (17 kJ/mol), indicating that the affinity of the CO2 molecules for other CO2 molecules is comparable to its interaction with the coordination network.

elements.content: Given the very large accessible void space and high BET surface area determined from the N2 isotherm at 77 K, we decided to investigate the new hua topology frameworks for gas storage at higher pressures. To the best of our knowledge, no high pressure adsorption studies have been conducted on (3,9)-c nets for applications in gas storage despite their relatively high surface areas. 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) were chosen for high pressure adsorption studies given their high BET surface areas. Sorption isotherms for methane were measured from 0 to 75 bar at 270, 278, and 298 K (a). 1­(Fe) exhibited the best adsorption capacity for CH4, with a gravimetric methane uptake of 289.7 cm3/g (0.207 g/g) at 35 bar and 398 cm3/g (0.285 g/g) at 65 bar at 278 K. 1­(Ni) exhibited gravimetric uptakes of 256 cm3/g (0.183 g/g) at 35 bar and 370 cm3/g (0.265 g/g) at 65 bar at 278 K. When the CH4 volumetric uptake is considered, the low framework density results in values of 151 cm3/cm3 (35 bar) and 208 cm3/cm3 (65 bar) for 1­(Fe) at 278 K and 134 cm3/cm3 (35 bar) and 194 cm3/cm3 (65 bar) at 278 K for 1­(Ni) ( and the Supporting Information).

In considering coordination networks for the storage of methane, is it important to determine the deliverable quantity of methane, typically within a 5–65 bar working range. It has been recently proposed that operation of absorbed natural gas (ANG) systems at the lower temperature of ∼270 K may be a viable option to substantially increase the quantity of deliverable methane. The deliverable methane quantity was substantially increased from 138 cm3/cm3 at 298 K to 175 cm3/cm3 at 270 K for 1­(Fe), while the deliverable methane quantity for 1­(Ni) was increased from 121 cm3/cm3 at 298 K to 159 cm3/cm3 at 278 K ( and Supporting Information). This contrasts with the effect of temperature upon the working capacity of some of the well-known MOFs such as Ni-MOF-74, HKUST-1, and PCN-14, all of which exhibit decreases in working capacity at reduced temperatures. Such reduced performance is likely a result of the presence of relatively strong binding sites for CH4, and consequently high Q st values, in turn leading to a high CH4 uptake at 5 bar and decreased working capacity over the 5–65 bar range (). Conversely, the relatively low Q st values for CH4 of 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe), 14.7 and 13.8 kJ/mol, respectively, mean that temperature has a larger impact upon uptake at higher pressures and, therefore, results in greater working capacity at lower temperatures. Lower Q st values might also be attractive due to a lower desorption and regeneration cost for the material (b). A material with low Q st values at low loadings coupled with high methane deliverable capacity may, therefore, be the optimal material for CH4 storage onboard vehicles at the lowered temperature of 270 K.

elements.content: The first examples of (3,9)-c hua topology networks are reported herein and have been constructed through the combination of the 3-c tris-pyridyl, NPy3, ligand matched with a dicarboxylate ligand of appropriate length, bpdc. The formation of the high connectivity 9-c trinuclear metal carboxylate cluster in the hua net provides a robust linkage for the synthesis of frameworks with some of the highest porosities and lowest crystallographic densities for known (3,9)-c nets. The hua topology networks reported herein exhibit good performance in the context of CH4 and CO2 gas storage, particularly at below ambient temperatures, e.g., 270 K. We also note that the nets reported herein are amenable to further crystal engineering studies due to the use of separate dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands, which provide exceptional scope for optimizing the gas storage properties of networks with hua topology afforded by the wide range of readily available dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The first examples of (3,9)-c hua topology networks are reported herein and have been constructed through the combination of the 3-c tris-pyridyl, NPy3, ligand matched with a dicarboxylate ligand of appropriate length, bpdc. The formation of the high connectivity 9-c trinuclear metal carboxylate cluster in the hua net provides a robust linkage for the synthesis of frameworks with some of the highest porosities and lowest crystallographic densities for known (3,9)-c nets. The hua topology networks reported herein exhibit good performance in the context of CH4 and CO2 gas storage, particularly at below ambient temperatures, e.g., 270 K. We also note that the nets reported herein are amenable to further crystal engineering studies due to the use of separate dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands, which provide exceptional scope for optimizing the gas storage properties of networks with hua topology afforded by the wide range of readily available dicarboxylate and tris-pyridyl ligands.

Dimethylacetamide (8.0 mL) was added to a mixture of NPy3 (40.0 mg, 0.0839 mmol), bpdc (63.2 mg, 0.260 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (63.0 mg, 0.260 mmol) in a glass vial to yield a red solution. The reaction mixture was shaken well at room temperature before being placed in an oven at 120 °C for 4 days to yield very dark red crystallites (50.3 mg, 44%). The mother liquor was removed, and the sample was soaked in DMA for 2 days. The sample was activated for sorption experiments by solvent exchange with acetonitrile (3 × 12 mL) over the course of 2 days before being heated at 60 °C for 16 h under vacuum.

cln_elements.content:
Large voids in the shape of a distorted octahedron exist in the network structure with dimensions of 10.847 Å between two NPy3 ligands stacked on each other, 13.382 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the bpdc ligand and 15.569 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the NPy3 ligand (Supporting Information). A void space of 71.5% was calculated by PLATON within the framework, and is reflected by the low crystallographic framework density of 0.525 cm3/g. The distorted octahedron results in larger internal volumes when compared to either the tetrahedral or the trigonal-pyramidal voids seen in other (3,9)-c nets.

The isostructural analogues with nickel, 1­(Ni), and iron, 1­(Fe), were also synthesized and verified by PXRD, but neither yielded crystals suitable for single crystal analysis. All frameworks were activated for gas sorption by solvent exchange with acetonitrile, followed by removal of the solvent under vacuum. Loss in crystallinity was observed when solvent exchange was attempted for the frameworks in either methanol or dichloromethane. The large void space of 71.5% present in the frameworks is reflected in the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) thermograms of the synthesized frameworks. Mass losses of 50.9, 60.1, and 62.1% were observed for 1­(Co), 1­(Fe), and 1­(Ni), respectively, between 25 and 200 °C, which we attribute to the loss of either DMF or DMA from the pores of the framework. The lower mass loss of 1­(Co) may be a result of the instability of this analogue in air, which is also reflected in the PXRD patterns.

Gas Sorption

The N2 isotherms at 77 K of 1­(Co), 1­(Ni), and 1­(Fe) all display a type I isotherm (a). The BET surface areas of 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) were determined to be 2552 and 2775 m2/g, respectively, which is comparable to previous reports in the literature (2316–2738 m2/g) for 9-c nets with ncb topology that contain ligands with biphenyl groups (). The lower surface of 1475 m2/g for 1­(Co) may be due to partial decomposition of the framework when exposed to air as suggested by the lower accessible pore volume determined from TGA (Supporting Information).

Given the very large accessible void space and high BET surface area determined from the N2 isotherm at 77 K, we decided to investigate the new hua topology frameworks for gas storage at higher pressures. To the best of our knowledge, no high pressure adsorption studies have been conducted on (3,9)-c nets for applications in gas storage despite their relatively high surface areas. 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) were chosen for high pressure adsorption studies given their high BET surface areas. Sorption isotherms for methane were measured from 0 to 75 bar at 270, 278, and 298 K (a). 1­(Fe) exhibited the best adsorption capacity for CH4, with a gravimetric methane uptake of 289.7 cm3/g (0.207 g/g) at 35 bar and 398 cm3/g (0.285 g/g) at 65 bar at 278 K. 1­(Ni) exhibited gravimetric uptakes of 256 cm3/g (0.183 g/g) at 35 bar and 370 cm3/g (0.265 g/g) at 65 bar at 278 K. When the CH4 volumetric uptake is considered, the low framework density results in values of 151 cm3/cm3 (35 bar) and 208 cm3/cm3 (65 bar) for 1­(Fe) at 278 K and 134 cm3/cm3 (35 bar) and 194 cm3/cm3 (65 bar) at 278 K for 1­(Ni) ( and the Supporting Information).

The high pressure CO2 isotherms for 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) from 0 to 30 bar were obtained at 278 and 298 K (a). 1­(Fe) adsorbs an exceptional 555.6 cm3/g (290.0 cm3/cm3) at 278 K and 387.1 cm3/g (202.1 cm3/cm3) at 30 bar and 298 K, while 1­(Ni) exhibits a lower quantity of adsorbed CO2 of 421.8 cm3/g (216.4 cm3/cm3) at 278 K and 306.8 cm3/g (157.4 cm3/cm3) at 298 K and 30 bar (Supporting Information). The high pressure CO2 isotherms for both 1­(Ni) and 1­(Fe) level out between 10 and 15 bar, possibly indicating flexibility and a change in the framework structure. From the high pressure CO2 adsorption data, Q st values of 23.2 kJ/mol for 1­(Ni) and 21.3 kJ/mol 1­(Fe) were determined, which correspond with the Q st values determined from the low pressure (0–1 bar) CO2 adsorption data (b).

Large voids in the shape of a distorted octahedron exist in the network structure with dimensions of 10.847 Å between two NPy3 ligands stacked on each other, 13.382 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the bpdc ligand and 15.569 Å between two Co trimer nodes linked by the NPy3 ligand (Supporting Information). A void space of 71.5% was calculated by PLATON within the framework, and is reflected by the low crystallographic framework density of 0.525 cm3/g. The distorted octahedron results in larger internal volumes when compared to either the tetrahedral or the trigonal-pyramidal voids seen in other (3,9)-c nets.

The isostructural analogues with nickel, 1(Ni), and iron, 1(Fe), were also synthesized and verified by PXRD, but neither yielded crystals suitable for single crystal analysis. All frameworks were activated for gas sorption by solvent exchange with acetonitrile, followed by removal of the solvent under vacuum. Loss in crystallinity was observed when solvent exchange was attempted for the frameworks in either methanol or dichloromethane. The large void space of 71.5% present in the frameworks is reflected in the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) thermograms of the synthesized frameworks. Mass losses of 50.9, 60.1, and 62.1% were observed for 1(Co), 1(Fe), and 1(Ni), respectively, between 25 and 200 °C, which we attribute to the loss of either DMF or DMA from the pores of the framework. The lower mass loss of 1(Co) may be a result of the instability of this analogue in air, which is also reflected in the PXRD patterns.

metadata.title: Construction of a Series of Porous (3,9)‑c Coordination Networks Using Dicarboxylate and Tris-pyridyl Ligands and Their Gas Storage Properties
